candidates.body: Some of the dependencies already updated MSRV and we can't remain behind without the risk of compiler breaks downstream

@zoedberg can you please re-open your pull request from the same branch, and I will schedule it for the v4.0 (not to introduce breaking changes into the master for now, to be able to do more fixes if they would be required)

candidates.title: Release v3.13.1 with related Wrapper: Clone constrained

candidates.title: Improve performance of unsigned integers
candidates.body:
benchmark comparison with 'critcmp':

```
group                     patched                                master
-----                     -------                                ------
i1024_add                 1.00     46.5±2.35ns        ? ?/sec    1.20     55.6±3.58ns        ? ?/sec
i1024_cmp_eq              1.00     15.8±0.91ns        ? ?/sec    1.40     22.3±1.16ns        ? ?/sec
i1024_cmp_mixed           1.00     10.1±0.38ns        ? ?/sec    1.73     17.5±0.66ns        ? ?/sec
i1024_cmp_pos             1.00     15.8±0.88ns        ? ?/sec    1.41     22.3±0.91ns        ? ?/sec
i1024_is_negative         1.00      3.5±0.12ns        ? ?/sec    4.68     16.2±0.56ns        ? ?/sec
i1024_is_positive         1.00     15.8±0.84ns        ? ?/sec    1.03     16.3±0.84ns        ? ?/sec
i1024_zero_is_negative    1.00     16.4±0.61ns        ? ?/sec    1.02     16.8±0.61ns        ? ?/sec
i1024_zero_is_positive    1.00     16.6±1.02ns        ? ?/sec    1.02     16.9±0.83ns        ? ?/sec
posit32_add               1.00     32.2±3.37ns        ? ?/sec    1.00     32.2±1.80ns        ? ?/sec
posit32_div               1.00     49.0±1.75ns        ? ?/sec    1.01     49.6±2.37ns        ? ?/sec
posit32_mul               1.00     26.2±1.42ns        ? ?/sec    1.00     26.3±1.11ns        ? ?/sec
posit32_sub               1.02     34.3±3.57ns        ? ?/sec    1.00     33.5±1.83ns        ? ?/sec
softposit32_add           1.04      9.9±0.38ns        ? ?/sec    1.00      9.5±0.39ns        ? ?/sec
softposit32_div           1.00     22.6±0.85ns        ? ?/sec    1.01     22.8±0.82ns        ? ?/sec
softposit32_mul           1.00      8.6±0.35ns        ? ?/sec    1.27     10.9±0.50ns        ? ?/sec
softposit32_sub           1.05     12.3±0.56ns        ? ?/sec    1.00     11.6±0.51ns        ? ?/sec
u1024_add                 1.00     32.1±1.93ns        ? ?/sec    1.00     32.0±1.04ns        ? ?/sec
u1024_cmp_eq              1.00      8.2±0.48ns        ? ?/sec    1.24     10.2±0.38ns        ? ?/sec
u1024_div                 1.00   296.9±13.45ns        ? ?/sec    1.00   297.5±16.29ns        ? ?/sec
u1024_mul                 1.00   416.2±23.71ns        ? ?/sec    1.28   533.3±16.83ns        ? ?/sec
u1024_sub                 1.00     42.1±1.41ns        ? ?/sec    1.00     42.0±1.64ns        ? ?/sec
```

All these tests were run on my laptop, in a not very controlled environment, so your mileage may vary. But the big differences in the i1024 tests, and in `u1024_cmp_eq`, are quite robust. There's a big and robust improvement in `u1024_mul` too, although I don't fully understand where that's coming from.

candidates.title: WASM in CI
candidates.body:
- [x] Add wasm-pack and wasm32 target to lint and test in CI.
- [x] Add caching to most actions to speed up CI builds.
- [x] Add features needed for wasm-pack to compile to headless chrome.

This PR does not_resolve #143, but it provides the tooling necessary to debug the issues.

candidates.title: fix conversion from decimal string into oct
Release apfloat and amplify with fixed no-std features
Re-export apfloat package
candidates.body:
There was incorrect setup for `std` and `alloc`-related features for apfloat package, which I have fixed

@6293 please review (I can't assign to you the review before you accept invitation to the org/repo I've sent you)

candidates.title: add `amplify_apfloat`: u256 backend apfloat (support IEEE octuple precision)
candidates.body:
https://github.com/internet2-org/rust-aluvm/issues/4

In [rustc_apfloat](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/tree/master/compiler/rustc_apfloat), the float values are stored as `u128`, limiting support of octuple precision which is described in IEEE 754 (2008 revision). My approach to support that is to modify the code and make it backed by `u256`, publishing it as a separate crate. 128bit-specific methods like `to_bits` are also updated to return `u256`.

candidates.title: add signed big int
candidates.body: https://github.com/internet2-org/rust-aluvm/issues/47

candidates.title: follow-up PR on clippy
candidates.body: Sorry to bother you again, I typo-ed on https://github.com/LNP-BP/rust-amplify/pull/111. What we needed to deref was `&mut std::fmt::Formatter`. Most likely I checked on `stable` compiler yesterday and thought it passed the `clippy` https://github.com/internet2-org/rust-aluvm/issues/38

candidates.title: clippy: needless borrow
candidates.body: trivial PR; this will shut up `clippy` on AluVM (https://github.com/internet2-org/rust-aluvm/runs/4727706297?check_suite_focus=true). Been ignored on this repo since they were inside `quote` macro

Moving to MSRV 1.36.0
candidates.body:
This will allow to use crates in rust-bitcoin projects, which will require rustc 1.36 from the next major release (https://github.com/rust-bitcoin/rust-bitcoin/issues/510#issuecomment-831231971)

NB: MSRV will change only when `stringly_conversions` and `serde_str_helpers` are not used. With them, MSRV will remain 1.41.1. This difference is already reflected in tests and README

candidates.title: Fixed no-std category
candidates.body:
The correct name of the category is `no-std`, not `no_std`.

Figured out when publishing a new version. Not important enough for a new release IMO, but better have it prepared for the next one.

candidates.title: A few more standard conversions for DeserBorrowStr
candidates.body:
This implements:

* `From<DeserBorrowStr> for String`
* `AsRef<str> for DeserBorrowStr`
* `Borrow<str> for DeserBorrowStr`

These are normally implemented for most stringly types and make use in
generic contexts easier.

This also bumps the version to `0.1.2`.

~~Would appreciate quick review, since I need this. Should be trivial anyway.
I plan to release a new version once this is merged.~~

Actually not that urgent, so don't worry.

candidates.title: v2.0 release
candidates.body:
- Wrapper derive macro, replacing old declarative macto `wrapper!`, with support for generics and complex internal structure
- Adoption of the new `stringly_conversions` and `serde_str_helpers` crates. Crates are re-exported.
- Removal of `Service`, `TryService` and `Exec` traits, which are moved into new `lnpbp_service` crate
- Removal of `async` feature and trait (no needed once service traits got moved)
- New simple `none!()` macro for semantic representation of empty type creation with `Default::default()`

candidates.title: Making `InetAddr` `Copy`
candidates.body:
Depends on acceptance of upstream changes: https://github.com/teawithsand/torut/pull/7

For now I am using patch to solve the issue

candidates.title: Fixed reference to paste in stringly_conversions
candidates.body:
`paste` was referenced relatively from the crate which caused failures
in downstream crates. This fixes it by reexporting `paste` and then
referencing it using `$crate`.

This blocks moving `rust-amplify::convert` to `stringly_conversions`.
I will yank the previous version after merging.

candidates.title: Remove requirement on std from `serde_str_helpers`
candidates.body:
The library doesn't need an operating system to work, just the
allocator. Thus it makes sense to switch it from `std` to `alloc`.

Do you think I should publish this change on crates.io right after merging or do you want some other changes before it?

candidates.title: Prepare for publishing stringly_conversions
candidates.body:
I will publish `stringly_conversions` after merging this and then make a PR to remove the code from parent crate and only reexport `stringly_conversions` and `DeserBorrowStr`

Regarding `DeserBorrowStr`, I can reexport it under old name (`CowHelper`), which will not affect compatibility but the old name is quite unclear. What should I do? So far I lean towards renaming it, since upstream fixes are as simple as `s/CowHelper/DeserBorrowStr/`. I could also write semver trick but I doubt it's worth the effort (unless you know of many *independent* projects using this crate).

candidates.title: Added description to serde_str_helpers Cargo.toml
candidates.body: I published the crate with this as it should be an obvious, non-controversial change. :)

candidates.title: Stringly conversions moved to a separate crate
candidates.body:
Some things improved:

* Fixed `&str` conversion
* Use `alloc` instead of `std` - we don't need OS.
* `serde_str_helpers` is optional (default off)

Things to resolve

- [x] It'd be better to generate a unique module name. There's a `paste` crate from reputable developer that may help but not sure if it'll work with arbitrary type names.
- [x] We need to publish `serde_str_helpers` and remove `path = "../serde_str_helpers"` from `Cargo.toml`

candidates.title: Move serde string deser helper to a separate crate
candidates.body:
This renames `CowHelper` to `DeserStrHelper`, which is clearer and moves
it to a separate crate with better documentation and tests.

Part of #7

I took a bit more time to polish it. :) Independent of #8 because it's a separate crate.

Should we reexport it in `amplify` under the old name or the new name?
